summary: While walking the Four Days Marches of Nijmegen I get to know new people, help them on their way, check my progress, and continue till I reach the finish line by tackling all possible setbacks. This same approach I take in my (voluntary) work: help others, plan, organise, and persevere till an optimal result is achieved. Due to my Artificial Intelligence and Applied Data Science background, and my experience with chairing board and committee work, I built a varied tool and skill set that I love to employ in developing applications that embrace the beautiful diversity of our world. I enjoy working on innovative projects that intersect multiple disciplines, and I believe that is the way to tackle the current challenges in this world. I am thus very happy to work at Nederlandse Spoorwegen with their big diversity in employees and complex challenges in one of the busiest public transport systems of the world.

projects.title: Masterclass Water Flood Risk Management

International exchange project with schools in Germany and Portugal about the management of water flood risk in the Netherlands.
Duration: 5 days.

projects.title: Master thesis "Utilizing linked open place data for entity resolution: a case study on Dutch genealogy at CBG"
projects.description:
Thesis written at Utrecht University (UU) and the Dutch Centre for Genealogy (CBG) for my master Applied Data Science. Performed under supervision of prof. dr. A.H.L.M. Pieters (UU), S.B. Dirks MSc (UU) and P. Woltjer (CBG).

Title: "Utilizing linked open place data for entity resolution: a case study on Dutch genealogy at CBG"

Abstract:
Entity resolution on genealogical documents is challenging due to spelling
errors, alternative name variants, and historic entity changes. Traditional
methods attempt to tackle these problems with string similarity methods,
which this research proposes to extend by enriching the recorded features
with additional place information such as place URIs, coordinates, and country
indicators. Based on a case study at the Dutch Centre for Genealogy,
this research contributes to extending entity resolution research, optimizing
and enriching family history (meta) studies, and investigating which
privacy-sensitive passport request documents can be disclosed.

First, linked open data sources are shown to retrieve unique place entities
belonging to recorded place names. Second, place, province and country
name similarities are calculated as well as coordinate distances within a coordinate
reference system that limits the distance distortions for the respective
countries. Third, the researched adaptation is shown to result in a significant
change in similarity values when a uniform weighting of feature similarities
is applied. However, contrary to the hypothesis, the similarity distributions
of compared documents that do and do not refer to an equivalent person
entity could not be distinguished in a more accurate way. Hence, future
studies are proposed that expand on this research by supervised learning of
weights and thresholds using validated candidate links from this research.

Keywords: Entity resolution, Linked open data, Genealogy, Geospatial
data, Content similarity

Grade: 8.8
Duration: 400 hours

projects.title: Bachelor thesis ‘’Creative art generation with a style-based architecture for generative adversarial networks’’
projects.description:
Thesis written at Radboud University, Artificial Intelligence department. Individually arranged research performed under primary supervision of prof. dr. A. Elgammal who at the time of my research was professor at the department of Computer Science at Rutgers University (NJ, USA), founder and director of the Art and Artificial Intelligence Laboratory there, and founder and CEO of Artrendex. The secondary supervision was done by dr. M.W. Tangermann and J. Thielen MSc, who at the time of my research were teachers at the department of Artificial Intelligence at Radboud University (Nijmegen, Netherlands) and specialised in brain-computer interfacing at Donders Centre for Brain, Cognition and Behaviour.   

Title: ‘’Creative art generation with a style-based architecture for generative adversarial networks’’

Abstract: Combining the state of the art Generative Adversarial Network (GAN) architecture of StyleGAN2 with the artistic style ambiguity loss of Creative Adversarial Network (CAN) has promises for improving the creative art field because styles are more controlled and higher resolutions can be reached than before. Even though my implementation does not achieve the expected results but suffers from common GAN problems, contributions are made towards the development and evaluation of such improved creative networks, and its societal relevance is discussed. A questionnaire for human evaluation is developed as I argue that objective GAN metrics give ambiguous results in the creative field. Furthermore, this area gives contributions towards Artificial General Intelligence, but also additional developments towards identifying deep fakes are required. Overall, my research together with follow up implementation improvements help understanding the possibilities and complexities of this intriguing field of creative computer-generated art.

Grade: 8.2
Duration: 505 hours

Title: “Zelfvoorzienende en overstromingsbestendige wijk” (self-sufficient and flood resistant neighbourhood).

projects.title: Thesis Folding of DNA
projects.description:
Thesis written at Utrecht University, Junior College Utrecht, U-Talent Academy campus program.
Research performed at and in collaboration with Hubrecht Institute, Utrecht.
Title: ‘’De invloed van het eiwit EZH2 en de hierdoor ontstane vouwing van het chromatine op de expressie van het HoxB1-gen’’ (The influence of the protein EZH2 and the resulting folding of the chromatin on the expression of the HoxB1-gene). 
Grade: 9.1
Duration: 215 hours.

Extracurricular excellence program learning students to draw and paint realistic still lifes and portraits on an excellent level.
Duration: 1 afternoon a week.

projects.title: Student in mathematics excellence program Wiskunde Top Talent Team
projects.description:
Extracurricular excellence program with as goal preparing students for participating in national mathematics competitions, including: Nederlandse Wiskunde Olympiade, Kangoeroewedstrijd, Pythagoras Olympiade and Wiskundetoernooi.
Duration: 60 hours.

profile_positions.description: NS operates one of the busiest public transport systems in the world, which gives complex and challenging tasks for maintaining and improving their services. As Java software developers of BAM (bijsturingsapplicatie materieel), we make sure that the trains can be deployed optimally, specifically when the time table is (slightly) different than planned due to delays, a defect, or other disruptions. With the use of a.o. this complex application, crises can be solved as quickly as possible such that the passengers can continue their travel.
profile_positions.title: Java Software Developer

profile_positions.description:
CognAC is the study association of Artificial Intelligence at the Radboud University Nijmegen. The main goal of CognAC is to provide its approximately 550 members with fun-, study, and career-oriented activities. 
The Chair of the board keeps supervision over the association and is responsible for leading the board meetings and general member meetings. The Chair is also responsible for the policy of the board and the execution of it, and that the official rules are complied with. Furthermore, the Chair keeps the full overview by attending meetings in- and outside the association and by making the year planning.
profile_positions.title: Chair

profile_positions.description: As a mentor of first year Artificial Intelligence Bachelor students at the Radboud University Nijmegen you guide the new students through their first year by hosting mentor meetings and having private talks. As the mentorship program is associated with the course Academic and Professional Skills 1, you also teach the students academic skills as writing a report and public speaking.
profile_positions.title: Mentor in first year's Artificial Intelligence mentorship program
Tutor in mathematics, physics, and chemistry

volunteer_experiences.description: A committee that organises a series of around 12 meetings for a group of LGBTQ+ people between 18 and 28 years old to educate about and discuss LGBTQ+ topics varying from sexuality to gender, sex to coming-out, and prejudices to parenting. For all these meetings we designed work forms ourselves to get informative and interactive discussions. Additionally, theme evenings are organised with talks about such topics for a broader and bigger audience and we educate our committee ourselves with professional training moments. Also, I together with two others am the founder of the Dito wide library with LGBTQ+ books such that people can find more recognition and educate themselves on topics. I was a member from June 2019 till September 2020, when I became the co-coordinator, and from December 2020 onward I took the position of coordinator of this committee. From January 2020 I also took the position of treasurer to keep track of our finances. From January 2020 till December 2021 I guided an introduction group with a diversity of people: different sexualities, genders, ethnicities, ages and life stages, and psychological backgrounds. This was thus during the COVID-19 pandemic and took a lot of flexibility while arranging these meetings because of multiple lockdowns, illness, changes of work forms and locations to make it safe (also online) but still interactive. To complete this series of meetings with a high level of education and safety also a lot of perseverance, creativity, and responsibility was needed and we did it very well according to the participants.

Together with a fellow member and the board of Dito we founded their senate to be able to advise the board on important matters for the association. We do this using our full-time board experience at our study associations, our networks we built since then, and our experience with volunteering within Dito. For this we read their board minutes and have regular meetings together with the board.

The senate of CognAC gives requested and unrequested advice to the board of the study association and discusses the long-term policies (longer than the year the board is in function) that we advise them to employ. For this we read their weekly board minutes, give elaborate feedback on their General Members Meeting documents, and keep an eye on other developments like the board’s wellbeing.

From the student wellbeing questionnaire sent by the Radboud University in 2017 and other reports of low student wellbeing, it became apparent that we wanted to do more for our students to improve on their wellbeing. As a reaction to this, a group of members from all study associations of the Faculty of Science founded the Student Aid project. This included a lot of communication and official paperwork with the faculty and the university to be allowed to set it up, we recruited and with student psychologists trained the student aides, promoted it to the students that they are standing by to give support where needed (with also a university webpage), kept in touch with them and representatives from the university, faculty, and studies (and their study associations), and evaluated and improved the project along the way. A Student Aid is a fellow student, who is an easily accessible first point of contact if you don’t know where to go for help, if you have questions, or if you want to share your story. They provide a listening ear or can guide you to solve the issue you are facing. Furthermore, they can help you find the right person to talk to, whether that is a study advisor, student psychologist or student counsellor. This way we tried lowering the threshold to seek for help. First a pilot study was developed to research the viability of the project and then it continued fully. After two and a half years of hard work and investment we trained new committee members to take over the responsibility of the project with their renewed insights and commitment. My involvement in the founding and development of this project in all its life stages shows my entrepreneurial skills, me wanting to help my fellow students with their wellbeing, communication and documentation skills to get the project approved by the university, and perseverance and commitment to make this project viable and get it running well.

Dito! is a volunteer organisation run by and for LGBTQ+ youth, which is based in Nijmegen. 
The Pink Week Committee organises the annual Pink Week on Campus at Radboud University and HAN. This is a week full of activities dedicated to the visibility, acceptance, and emancipation of LGBTQ+ people.

A committee that organises the annual Artificial Intelligence Parentsday at the Radboud University. On this day family members and friends of an AI student can get to know the study, the university, and CognAC.

Olympus is the umbrella association of the study associations within the FNWI, Foundation Bèta Bedrijven Beurs, and CognAC.
The Beta Boards Weekend Committee organises the annual beta boards weekend to enhance the integration of the boards within the FNWI, including CognAC.

To welcome the new first year Bachelor students of Artificial Intelligence, an orientation week is organised with a lot of fun and educational activities to help them to get to know each other and the city of Nijmegen, and to prepare them for the start of their studies. Together with two fellow older year students I guided a group of these students during this week (did this in two different years), which was a lot of fun and hearth warming to see them develop during this week and the years to come. This shows my people skills and responsibility to help them get started well.
A committee that designs and creates an annual yearbook for the study association. This year the first almanac of CognAC is being made.
A committee that organises discussion evenings in which topics related to Artificial Intelligence are explained and discussed.

A committee that organises the annual Real Life Monopoly game in which students must visit streets across the Netherlands while doing all sorts of quests. As treasurer you are responsible for the bookkeeping of the committee on top of the general member tasks.
A committee that organises study related activities like study sessions for courses that students need extra help in, or workshops to gain additional skills.

A committee that helps familiarise first-year students with the study association. This year the First Years Committee organised a cantus, a hike and catch, and a Valentine’s day auction, the latter to raise money for charity.
